head.title: A New Way to Read The Law at Home

hedline.hl1: A New Way to Read The Law at Home

Beginning next month, students will be able to earn a law degree entirely on line.

Kaplan Educational Centers, a Washington Post Company subsidiary best known for its test-coaching services, is opening the Concord University School of Law, in which students will take all of their courses over the Internet.

The school will not be accredited by the American Bar Association, however, and as a result graduates will face some limits to where they can practice law. California is one state that will welcome them.

The school, which began accepting applications last week (www.concord.kaplan.edu), expects to attract people whose careers, family obligations or geographic locations make it hard for them to attend traditional law schools.
The cost, $4,200 a year for a four-year law degree program, will be far below the cost at most private universities and even less than at many public ones.
